responses.content: We saw that markets where we had rolled out Apple Intelligence performed better year-over-year on the iPhone 16 family than those where it was not available. Users are utilizing all features, from Writing Tools to Image Playground and Genmoji. We only had about two and a half weeks of the second release in the quarter, but early indications are positive.

Greater China revenue was down 11% year-over-year. Over half of this decline was driven by a change in channel inventory from the beginning to the end of the quarter. We have not rolled out Apple Intelligence in China yet. However, it remains the most competitive market in the world. We are seeing fiscal stimulus occurring recently.

Innovation that drives efficiency is a good thing. Our tight integration of silicon and software serves us well. We use a hybrid model with on-device processing and private cloud compute. We've always been prudent with capital expenditure and will continue to leverage this hybrid model.

We set an all-time record for upgraders, and the install base hit a new all-time high. The iPhone 16 has outperformed the iPhone 15 in the period from launch to the end of the December quarter. Markets with Apple Intelligence outperformed those without.

We have great results in emerging markets. India set a December quarter record, and iPhone was the top-selling model there. We are opening four new stores in India. We have modest share in these huge markets, so there is lots of upside.

I believe Apple Intelligence will go mainstream. As the base of compatible devices (iPhone 15 Pro and iPhone 16 lineup) grows, usage will grow. Features like summarization are becoming indispensable. We are rolling out more languages in April.

We are guiding to 46.5% to 47.5% for the March quarter. We expect FX headwinds to impact margins sequentially, but this will be offset by favorable costs and services mix. We lose some leverage moving from Q1 to Q2, but we feel the guidance range is very strong.

Services had an all-time record quarter, growing 14%. Strength was broad-based across all geographic segments and service offerings. Transacting and paid accounts reached all-time highs, with over 1 billion paid subscriptions. We are focused on improving the breadth and quality of offerings.

Product gross margin improved 300 basis points sequentially to 39.3%, driven by favorable mix and leverage from the launch quarter. Customers are gravitating toward Pro products. We are also in a favorable commodity environment.
We have had a disciplined pricing strategy that has served us well, balancing short-term and long-term goals. We don't expect to depart from this strategy.

questions: Can you share details on how Apple Intelligence is impacting iPhone demand and which features are most used?
Regarding China, aside from macro, are there headwinds from shifting preferences to domestic brands or the lack of Apple Intelligence?
Does the potential for lower compute costs (e.g., DeepSeek) change your view on margins or execution?
Is there room for significant form factor innovation in the smartphone market in the next 2-3 years?
What do you attribute the record iPhone upgrade strength to? Did Apple Intelligence play a role?
How did the thinner form factor of the iPad Pro help sales, and what is consumer feedback?
How durable is the growth in emerging markets, and can it offset China headwinds?
Regarding March quarter gross margin guidance being flat sequentially, what are the puts and takes, and is FX a major factor?
Can you address channel inventory across regions and if the China reduction implies a normal progression for March?
How should investors think about top-line or margin headwinds from regulatory burdens on the Services business?
How sustainable is the double-digit growth in Mac and iPad? Does AI influence Mac volumes like it does iPhone?
How much of the supply chain planning in India is for domestic growth versus diversification?
How do you square the momentum of Apple Intelligence with iPhone revenue being relatively flat compared to previous years?
Where can Services gross margins go over the intermediate term given the current 75% level?
How much of Mac growth is driven by silicon innovation versus a replacement cycle?
Is there more upside to product gross margins from AI devices or other levers?
What accelerates Apple Intelligence adoption: time/languages or marketing spend? Is there a tipping point?
Might a wider range of pricing unlock further market share gains?
How do you see potential tariff impacts under the new administration?
Do you see the upgraded Siri as the killer app for Apple Intelligence?
How should we think about the average useful life of devices and the refresh opportunity from the COVID cohort?
